text: # Introduction Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a technique that combines information retrieval with large language models. It allows models to ground their answers in external documents. # Chunking Problems Bad chunking is the number one reason RAG systems fail in production. If chunks are too small, context is lost. If chunks are too large, retrieval becomes noisy. # Industry Perspective In real-world systems, chunking strategies are tuned per document type. Self-improving RAG systems must detect chunking failures automatically.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a technique that combines information retrieval with large language models.
It allows models to ground their answers in external documents.
Bad chunking is the number one reason RAG systems fail in production.

If chunks are too small, context is lost.
If chunks are too large, retrieval becomes noisy.
In real-world systems, chunking strategies are tuned per document type.
Self-improving RAG systems must detect chunking failures automatically.
